content: {"primary_diagnosis":{"name":"Systemic Lupus Erythematosus with Class III/IV Lupus Nephritis","confidence":0.85,"icd_code":"M32.4","reasoning":"The patient presents with hematuria, proteinuria, RBC casts, and dysmorphic RBCs indicating glomerular bleeding. Low complement C3 and C4, positive ANA 1:160, and elevated ESR/CRP support an immune complex mediated process. The acute rise in creatinine, hypertension, edema, and bilateral renal enlargement are classic for lupus nephritis. The intermittent dysuria and prior antibiotic courses are likely secondary to urinary tract infections, but the systemic findings point to SLE as the underlying etiology."},"differential_diagnoses":[{"name":"IgA Nephropathy","confidence":0.25,"icd_code":"N00.4","reasoning":"IgA nephropathy can present with hematuria and proteinuria, but it typically does not cause low complement levels or ANA positivity. The presence of low C3/C4 and ANA makes this less likely."},{"name":"Post‑streptococcal Glomerulonephritis","confidence":0.15,"icd_code":"N00.0","reasoning":"Post‑streptococcal GN can cause low C3 but usually has normal C4 and is associated with a recent streptococcal infection, which is not reported."},{"name":"Acute Interstitial Nephritis","confidence":0.10,"icd_code":"N04.1","reasoning":"AIN can cause renal dysfunction and eosinophiluria, but RBC casts and dysmorphic RBCs are not typical. Also complement levels are usually normal."},{"name":"Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis","confidence":0.10,"icd_code":"N00.6","reasoning":"MPGN can present with low complement and proteinuria, but ANA positivity is less common."},{"name":"Urinary Tract Infection","confidence":0.05,"icd_code":"N39.0","reasoning":"Urinary symptoms and mixed flora on culture suggest infection, but the systemic findings and renal involvement exceed a simple UTI."}],"key_findings":["Dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts on urinalysis","Low complement C3 and C4 with positive ANA","Rapidly rising creatinine and bilateral renal enlargement","Hypertension and edema"],"diagnostic_tests":[{"test":"Serum anti‑dsDNA antibody","purpose":"Confirm SLE activity and correlate with renal disease","priority":"urgent"},{"test":"Renal biopsy","purpose":"Determine lupus nephritis class and guide therapy","priority":"urgent"},{"test":"ANCA panel","purpose":"Exclude ANCA‑associated vasculitis","priority":"routine"},{"test":"Hepatitis B & C serology","purpose":"Rule out hepatitis‑associated GN","priority":"routine"},{"test":"Urine culture with sensitivity","purpose":"Identify and treat any active infection","priority":"immediate"},{"test":"Serum albumin","purpose":"Assess hypoalbuminemia and guide ACEi/ARB therapy","priority":"routine"}],"management_plan":{"immediate_actions":["Order urgent anti‑dsDNA and renal biopsy","Start empiric high‑dose IV methylprednisolone 500 mg daily for 3 days","Initiate ACE inhibitor (lisinopril 10 mg daily) for proteinuria BP control","Provide hydration and monitor urine output","Order repeat urinalysis and serum creatinine in 48 hours"],"medications":[{"drug":"Methylprednisolone","dose":"500 mg","route":"IV","duration":"3 days","rationale":"Rapid control of active lupus nephritis"},{"drug":"Lisinopril","dose":"10 mg","route":"PO","duration":"ongoing","rationale":"Reduce proteinuria control hypertension"},{"drug":"Hydroxychloroquine","dose":"200 mg","route":"PO","duration":"ongoing","rationale":"Disease‑modifying therapy for SLE"},{"drug":"Probenecid","dose":"250 mg","route":"PO","duration":"as needed","rationale":"Prevent uric acid nephropathy if hyperuricemia develops"}],"monitoring":["Serum creatinine and eGFR","Urine protein/creatinine ratio","Blood pressure","CBC (for steroid side effects)","Serum electrolytes (especially potassium)"],"consultations":[{"specialty":"Nephrology","urgency":"immediate","reason":"Renal biopsy and management of lupus nephritis"},{"specialty":"Rheumatology","urgency":"immediate","reason":"Confirm SLE diagnosis and initiate disease‑modifying therapy"}]},"red_flags":["Rapidly rising creatinine (>0.5 mg/dL in 48 hrs)","Severe hypertension (>180/110 mmHg)","Active urinary sediment with >50 RBC/hpf","Systemic symptoms (fever, rash, arthritis)","Signs of infection (fever, chills)"],"patient_education":["Take medications exactly as prescribed; do not skip doses of steroids or hydroxychloroquine","Maintain adequate hydration; avoid NSAIDs and nephrotoxic drugs","Monitor for signs of infection (fever, chills) and report promptly","Keep a log of blood pressure and urine output","Attend all follow‑up appointments and labs"],"follow_up":{"timing":"2 weeks for repeat labs and clinical assessment; 1 month for nephrology review","conditions":"Return sooner if worsening edema, hypertension, decreased urine output, or new systemic symptoms"},"confidence_in_assessment":0.85,"uncertainties":["Exact lupus nephritis class (needs biopsy), potential need for additional immunosuppressants (e.g., mycophenolate mofetil)","Differential diagnosis of other complement‑consuming GN (e.g., MPGN) cannot be excluded without biopsy"]}
